# Airway Anatomy

*   23 generations of airways
*   Dichotomous branching
*   1-15: Conducting airways
*   16-23: Respiratory airways
*   Small airways: size < 2mm *internal diameter*

**Diagrammatic Representation of Airway Generations and Corresponding Data**

The diagram illustrates the branching of airways from the trachea down to alveolar sacs, categorized into a "Conducting zone" and a "Transitional and respiratory zones".

*   **Conducting zone:** Trachea, Bronchi, Bronchioles, Terminal bronchioles
*   **Transitional and respiratory zones:** Respiratory bronchioles, Alveolar ducts (T₃, T₂, T₁), Alveolar sacs (T)

A handwritten note indicates "start of smallest airways < 2mm" pointing to Generation 5.

<!-- Page 5 -->



# Small Airways vs Large Airways

| Feature                 | Large Airways                       | Small Airways             |
| :---------------------- | :---------------------------------- | :------------------------ |
| Generation              | Up to 8th generation                | 8th and beyond            |
| Cross Sectional Area    | Small                               | Large                     |
| Cartilage               | Present                             | Absent                    |
| Surfactant Lining       | Absent                              | Present                   |
| Airflow                 | Turbulent Convection                | Laminar Diffusion         |
| Resistance              | 75-90%                              | 10-25%                    |
| Collateral ventilation  | Absent                              | Present                   |
| Effect of lung volume   | Reduces with reduced lung volume    | Unaffected by lung volume |

---

<!-- Page 6 -->



# Spirometry

*   Most widely used lung function test
*   <u>Most airway resistance occurs between 4th – 8th generation airways</u>
*   FEV1 commonly large airway obstruction
    *   Dependent on lung volumes
    *   Elasticity
    *   Patient effort

**Diagram Labels:**
*   PEF, MEF
*   FEF 25%
*   FEF 50%
*   FEF 75%
*   FVC
*   Volume (L)
*   Expiration
*   Inspiration
*   Flow (liters per second)
*   FIF 25%
*   FIF 50%
*   FIF 75%

---

<!-- Page 7 -->



# Role of Sound waves in lung function

*   Arthur DuBois (1956)
    *   ✓ **Forced Oscillation Technique (FOT)**
    *   ✓ Single frequency sound waves to tidal breathing
*   Modified Ohm's Law
    Airflow = $\frac{\Delta \text{pressure}}{\text{Resistance}}$ $\rightarrow$ Resistance = $\frac{\Delta P}{\text{Flow}}$
    *   *Handwritten notes:*
        *   pressure difference at both ends of tube
        *   Flow (sound) of air in tube
*   ✓ Impedence (Zrs) is the pressure to be overcome to maintain forward airflow
    *   Considers the properties of conducting pathways and alveoli

*Graph Labels:*
*   Patient's Quiet Breathing
*   Tremolo Oscillation
*   Measured Waveform

---

<!-- Page 8 -->



# Impedence of Respiratory system
*The pressure required to overcome the resistance inside tube/Airways.*



## Components of Respiratory System Impedance

*   **Resistance (Rrs)**
    *   Influenced by: Airway calibre, Airflow determined

*   **Reactance (Xrs)**
    *   Composed of:
        *   **Inertance**
            *   Derived from: Volume of gas
            *   *Annotation:* ? Obvious/Inertia Provides Inertia for new air Entry
        *   **Elastance / capacitance**
            *   Derived from: Elastic properties, Small airways, alveoli
            *   *Annotation:* Ability to Expand & absorb the pressure



## Total Respiratory System Impedance

$Zrs = Rrs + Xrs$

---

<!-- Page 9 -->



# Role of Sound Frequency (Hz)

*   Distance travelled by sound is determined by frequency
    *   Higher frequencies -> shorter distances
    *   Lower Frequencies -> longer distances

R5: Resistance @ 5Hz (Entire Lung)
R20: Resistance @ 20Hz (Large Airways)
R5-R20: Peripheral airway resistance

X5: Reactance @5Hz (Entire lung Elastance)
X20: Reactance @20Hz (inertance)

| :---------- | :-------- |
| 2-5MHz      | 5-10MHz   |
| 30cm        | 9cm       |

<!-- Page 11 -->



# Impulse Oscillometry

*   Michaelson in 1976
    *   **Square wave pattern** of sound oscillation
        *   Multiple frequencies simultaneously (Handwritten note: "Advantage" pointing to this line)
    *   Impulse Oscillometry System (IOS)
*   Frequencies from **3Hz – 30Hz at a time**

---

**Diagrams:**

*   **Sinusoidal wave oscillation of FOT**
    (A sine wave is depicted)
*   **Square wave oscillation of IOS**
    (A square wave is depicted)

---

**Images:**

*   A computer setup displaying data, connected to a medical device, likely the Impulse Oscillometry System.
*   A patient undergoing an Impulse Oscillometry test, with a device held to their mouth and nose.

---

<!-- Page 12 -->



# IOS vs FOT

| FOT                               | IOS                                     |
| :-------------------------------- | :-------------------------------------- |
| Tidal Breathing                   | Tidal Breathing                         |
| Sinusoidal wave oscillation       | Square Wave Oscillation                 |
| Single Frequency at a time        | Multiple Frequencies in same sitting    |
| Multiple measurements             | Few measurements                        |
| Better Temporal resolution        | Poor Temporal Resolution                |
| Cumbersome, large                 | Easy to perform, portable               |
| Poor Signal Noise Characteristics | Better Signal Noise Characteristics     |

As present since long time
Dis Adv:-

Airway Oscillometry
Or
Lung Oscillation
Technique

---

<!-- Page 13 -->



# How to Perform

*   Comfortable seated position, nose clips
*   Neck neutral
*   Cheek support [cheek can absorb some pressure]
*   Mouth piece – firm seal
*   Tidal breathing for 30s
*   Minimum 3 readings I.O.T.
*   Coherence >0.9 (near +0.1 is good)
    *   quality of result

*(Text from image labels)*
*   Cheek support
*   Neck in neutral position

X5 is usually a -ve value, because the pressure is Absorbed therefore Lost in the Alveoli. so 5Hz [X5] reaches upto level of Alveoli

**Definitions:**
*   **Fres:** Resonant Frequency (point at which elastance = inertance)
*   **AX:** Area of Reactance
    *   Area under Fres and b/w X5
    *   Determinant of tissue elastance

More air gets trapped in them. + tissue becomes less Elastic → so more -ve X5 seen → AX ↑res --- Oscillogram Resistance or Reactance (cmH20/L/s) 1.5 1.0 0.5 0 -0.5 -1.0 R₅ R₂₀ X₅ X₂₀ AX F_res Frequency (Hz) Resistance Reactance --- # Oscillogram - ILD ## Graph **Y-axis:** Resistance or Reactance (cmH2O/L/s) **X-axis:** Frequency (Hz) **Legend:** * --- Resistance * - - - Reactance **Graph Annotations:** * R5 * R20 (not much change in R5 - R20) * X20 * AX (shaded area) * X5 → more -ve [as they loose their Elastic property] Absorb More pressure * F_res ↑ses & shifts more to right. --- # Interpretation | Diseases | R5 | R20 | X5 | Fres | | :------------------------------------------ | :---------------- | :-- | :--------------------------------------------- | :--------------------------------------------- | | Proximal Airway Obstruction | ↑ (Entire lung) | ↑ | N (As smaller airways not affected) | N | | Peripheral Airway Obstruction (Small airways) | ↑ | N | ↑ (Because of air trapping/loss of elasticity) | ↑ | | Lung Restriction | N | N | ↑ | ↑ | * Bronchodilator Response: 40% decrease in R5; 50% increase in X5; 80% decrease in AX (R5 X5 AX 40-50-80) * Bronchoconstrictor Response: 20 – 50% increase in R5 + 20-80% decrease in X5 Eur Respir Rev 2022; 31: 210208 --- # Example * 40 year old male, known bronchial asthma since 25 years. # FENO Fractional exhaled nitric oxide DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM 1 --- # INDICATIONS * Assessment of cough, wheezing, and dyspnea * Identifying eosinophilic asthma phenotype * * Assessing the potential response to anti-inflammatory agents*, notably inhaled corticosteroids (ICS)* *Rx response* * To guide changes in anti-inflammatory medications in a step-wise manner* *↑ne ↓dse dose* *step up / step down* * To assess whether airway inflammation is contributing to poor asthma control, particularly in the presence of other contributors (eg, rhinosinusitis, anxiety, gastroesophageal reflux, obesity, continued allergen exposure) DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM --- # NO PRODUCTION * In the respiratory tract, *NO* is produced by a wide variety of cell types and is generated through conversion of $\underline{\text{L-arginine}}$ to $\underline{\text{L-citrulline}}$ by the action of $\underline{\text{nitric oxide synthase (NOS)}}$. * *NO* production is induced in the bronchial epithelium by $\underline{\text{interferon gamma (IFN}\gamma\text{)}}$ via $\underline{\text{Janus kinases (JAK)/STAT-1}}$ signaling. --- **Diagram Text:** * L-Arginine * O$_2$ * NADPH, Heme, THB4 * NOS * Citulline * Nitric oxide (No) **NOS Types:** * NOS1/nNOS (Neural) * NOS2/iNOS (Inducible) * NOS3/eNOS (Endothelial) --- DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM --- # ROLE OF NO ## Physiology (Low Concentration: [fM-pM]) * Regulates the tone of the airway * Regulates pulmonary blood flow * Bronchodilator * Surfactant production * Regulates the permeability of the alveolar capillary membrane * Stimulates the ciliary beat * Anti-inflammatory effect * Mediator in local immunity processes * Neurotransmission (iNANC) ## Pathophysiology (High Concentration: [nM], ++++ iNOS) * Bronchial hyperreactivity * Mucus hypersecretion * Vascular permeability * Vasodilation * Proinflammatory effect * Inhibition of ciliary motility * Production of free radicals * Cytotoxicity DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM --- # Mechanisms of FeNO Elevation in Type 2 Inflammation (49:40) TH2 → IL4, IL5, IL13 ILC2 → IL5, IL13 ## TYPE 2 INFLAMMATION * **IL-5** * Activation of immune cells * JAK-2, STAT-3 * IL-5R * Eosinophil * Differentiation, activation and survival of eosinophils * **IL-4**, **IL-13** * JAK-1, JAK-3, STAT-6 * IgE production * Smooth muscle hypertrophy * iNOS * Elevated NO production by bronchial epithelial cells * FeNO *(Handwritten notes on the right side of the diagram)* (5) ↓ (4, 13) ↓ JAK-STAT ↓ IL3 ↓ IgE ↓ Aines --- # METHOD * Expirate is continuously sampled by the NO analyzer * patient should be seated comfortably * mouthpiece at the proper height and position * Nose clip should not be used (Curved in imp.OT) * Insert a mouthpiece and inhale over 2 to 3 seconds through the mouth to TLC, or near TLC then exhale immediately, because breath-hold results in NO accumulation * The instrument display and audio signals guide the user to the correct exhalation pressure. DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP (unclear text) --- To ensure accuracy and repeatability of results, the FeNO detection process in the adult 10-second mode of the NIOX VERO® requires patients to maintain an exhalation flow rate of 0.05L/s (+/- 10%) for 10 seconds. * Children who are not able to perform the 10 second test, the 6 second test is an alternative L/min/second DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP FACI EOARM --- # Patient Factors Influencing Exhaled NO Value * **Age**: In adults, there is no relationship between exhaled NO level and age, but it has been reported that, in children, Feno increases with age. * **Respiratory maneuvers**: Because spirometric maneuvers have been shown to transiently reduce exhaled NO levels it is recommended that NO analysis be performed before spirometry. * **Airway caliber**: Feno level may vary with bronchial obstruction and after bronchodilators. * **Food, medication and beverages.**: Patients should refrain from eating and drinking before NO analysis. An increase in feno has been noticed after intake of nitrates and nitrate containing foods such as lettuce, radish etc, drinking water and ingestion of caffeine may lead to transiently altered Feno. DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM --- * Alcohol ingestion reduces Feno in patients with asthma and healthy subjects ✓ * Exhaled NO falls after treatment with inhaled or oral corticosteroids and after inhaled NO synthase inhibitors ✓ * Smoking * Chronically reduced level of feno have been demonstrated in cigarette smokers. ✓ * Subjects should not smoke in the hour before measurements ✓ * Infection: Upper and lower respiratory tract viral infections may lead to increased levels of exhaled NO in asthma ✓ * HIV infection is associated with reduction in exhaled NO ✓ * Hypoxia: decreases exhaled NO. ✓ DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM --- # INTERPRETATION The normal level of FeNO is 20 to 30 parts per billion. What Are the Clinically Significant Cut Points for FENO? **Adults** * Low FENO: < 25 ppb * Intermediate FENO: 25 - 50 ppb * High FENO: > 50 ppb **Children** * Low FENO: < 20 ppb * Intermediate FENO: 20 - 35 ppb * High FENO: > 35 ppb DR. sectionTitle: SPECIFIC CAUSES OF SMALL AIRWAYS DISEASES [Bronchiolar involvement]
content:
# SPECIFIC CAUSES OF SMALL AIRWAYS DISEASES [Bronchiolar involvement]

*   ✓ Infection especially in children → post viral bronchiolitis
*   ✓ CTDs
*   ✓ Transplant → B.O. obliterans → HP
*   Environmental / occupational
*   Drug induced
*   Bronchiolar involvement in diseases also involving large airways Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease Bronchiectasis, including cystic fibrosis Asthma
*   ✓ Diffuse panbronchiolitis

Eur Respir Rev 2013; 22: 126, 131-147
DOI: 10.1183/09059180.00001313
Copyright © ERS 2013

REVIEW
✓ Small airways diseases, excluding asthma and COPD: an overview

DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP PACI EDARM 16

---

<!-- Page 46 -->

- Small airways obstruction may lead to
- A reduction in airflow
- Increased airways resistance
- Gas trapping
- Inhomogeneity of ventilation
- Early diagnosis and treatment is needed to **prevent disease progression**

DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM 17

---

<!-- Page 47 -->



# DIAGNOSTIC METHODS for SAD

*   **Pulmonary Function Test**
    *   Spirometry ✓
    *   Oscillometry ✓
    *   Exhaled NO ✓
    *   Plethysmography \*
    *   Dynamic compliance \*
    *   Inert gas washout \*

*   **IMAGING**
    *   High resolution CT
    *   Hyperpolarised helium ✓
    *   MRI ✓ (can show ventilation pattern)
    *   2D gamma scintigraphy ✓
    *   SPECT ✓ (single photon emission CT)
    *   PET ✓

*   **BIOPSY**

Dr. Bharath Kathi MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM
18

---

<!-- Page 48 -->



# SPIROMETRY

*   In health, the main site of airways resistance is the 4th-8th airway generation
*   FEV1 largely reflects large airways obstruction $\approx$ MEFR
*   Forced Expiratory Flow between 25 and 75% of the FVC (FEF25-75)- latter part of the vital capacity is affected by increased resistance in small airways as lung volume decreases.
*   **DISADVANTAGES**
    *   Poor reproducibility as it is dependent on the FVC
    *   There is poor correlation with other markers of small airways disease such as gas trapping and histological evidence of small airways inflammation

# DYNAMIC COMPLIANCE
asked on (10 marks) (OPD)

$C = \frac{dv}{dp} = \text{change in volume per unit change in pressure}$
*   Static means we are not taking airflow into consideration
*   Dynamic means we are taking Air flow (movement)

$\checkmark$ Dynamic compliance, defined as the change in lung volume during airflow produced by a given change in transpulmonary pressure, is normally independent of breathing frequency.

$\circledast$ In normal persons, dynamic compliance closely approximates inspiratory static lung compliance (80%) and remains essentially unchanged even when breathing frequency is increased up to 60 breaths per minute.

$\checkmark$ This indicates that lung units that are parallel with each other normally fill and empty uniformly and synchronously, even when airflow is high and the change in lung volume is rapid.

*   The rate of filling and emptying of a lung unit depends on its time constant—that is, the product of its resistance and compliance.

# Dynamic compliance

*   Lung units with high resistance take longer to fill and empty more slowly compared to units with low resistance. [Handwritten: SAD, Filled slow, Emptied late]
*   Patchy narrowing of small peripheral airways produces regional differences in time constants.
*   At low breathing frequencies, when the rate of airflow is low, ventilation is fairly evenly distributed.
*   As the breathing frequency increases: ventilation tends to be distributed to areas that offer the least resistance to airflow. So lung units fed by narrowed airways receive proportionally less ventilation than do areas of the lung where the airways remain open.
*   This frequency dependence of compliance was first noted in a patient with emphysema.

### 3. NUCLEAR MEDICINE

Scintigraphy uses radioactive tracers to obtain images of organs and/or record their functioning. It is a powerful tool that has been widely used to visualize and characterize intrapulmonary drug delivery in airways diseases such as asthma and COPD. It allows the measurement of overall lung deposition, and, to some extent, regional deposition (such as the lung periphery).

The accompanying scintigraphic images from a patient with asthma show aerosol deposition of radioactively labeled albuterol particles in the (a) posterior thorax and (b) anterior thorax, which were recorded sequentially, with the patient repositioned between views. Red areas indicate regions of highest radioactivity and black of least radioactivity.

# SPECT : Single Photon Emission Computed Tomography

### Single-photon emission computed tomography

Single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) is a 3-dimensional nuclear imaging technique involving use of radioactive tracers to highlight certain features of organs/tissues, such as the patchy distribution of small airways disease. Single-photon emission computed tomography images are sometimes combined with traditional computed tomography images to correlate functional and structural features.

The accompanying Technegas ventilation SPECT/computed tomography (CT) fusion image shows the axial dimension of a 68-year-old man with moderately severe COPD. It highlights well-ventilated areas of the lung (bright yellow), less-ventilated areas (red) and nonventilated areas (black). Green indicates emphysema.
It is apparent that poorly ventilated areas tend to correspond with areas of emphysema.
